text.title: Activate Google Voice Typing on PC or Mac
text.head: Activate Google Voice Typing on PC or Mac
text.p: This wikiHow teaches you how to use your voice instead of the keyboard to type in Google Docs or Google Slides on a computer. This feature is only available in the Google Chrome web browser.
text.head: Steps
Voice Typing in Google Docs

list.item: Make sure your microphone is enabled and ready to use. If you’re using a Mac, see Activate a Microphone on Mac. If you’re using Windows, see Record Audio on a PC to make a test recording.
Open Google Chrome. It’s in the Applications folder on a Mac and in the All Apps area of the Start menu on a PC.
Go to https://drive.google.com. If you’re not already signed in to your Google account, follow the on-screen instructions to sign in now.
Open the document you want to edit. If you want to create a new document, click + New at the top-left corner of the page, then select Google Doc.
Click the menu. It’s at the top of Google Docs.
Click . A microphone panel will appear.
Click the microphone when you’re ready to speak.

Speak the words you want to type. Speak clearly at a regular volume and speed. The words you say will appear on the screen just as they are spoken.
Say these terms to add punctuation and new lines where necessary: Period, Comma, Exclamation point, Question mark, New line, New paragraph.
You can also use voice commands to format the text. Some examples: Bold, Italicize, Underline, All caps, Capitalize, Highlight, Increase font size, Line spacing double, Align center, Apply 2 columns.
You can move around the document with voice commands. Say Go to or Move to, followed by the desired location (e.g., Start of paragraph, End of document, Next word, Previous page).
Click the microphone again when you’re finished. The words you say will no longer appear in the document as you speak.

text.head: Voice Typing in Google Slides Speaker Notes

list.item:
Make sure your microphone is enabled and ready to use. If you’re using a Mac, see Activate a Microphone on Mac. If you’re using Windows, see Record Audio on a PC to make a test recording.
You can only use voice typing in the speaker notes, not the slides themselves.
Open Google Chrome. It’s in the Applications folder on a Mac and in the All Apps area of the Start menu on a PC.
Go to https://drive.google.com. If you’re not already signed in to your Google account, follow the on-screen instructions to sign in now.
Click the Slides presentation you want to edit. This opens the file for editing.
Click the menu. It’s at the top of Google Slides.
Click . This opens the speaker notes, as well as a small panel with a microphone on it.
Click the microphone when you’re ready to speak.

Speak the words you want to type. Speak clearly at a regular volume and speed. The words you say will appear on the screen just as they are spoken.
Say these terms to add punctuation and new lines where necessary: Period, Comma, Exclamation point, Question mark, New line, New paragraph.
Click the microphone again when you’re finished. The changes you made to the file will be saved immediately.
